answers.answer:
You can enter Romania with temporary protection, with the right of short-stay (for Ukrainian nationals with a valid passport), or as an asylum seeker. Non-Ukrainian nationals may enter for transit purposes with a visa on arrival, and specific rules apply to Russian citizens.

For detailed information, please visit the website `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania` and read under the sections like 'Temporary protection', 'Short stay', 'Asylum seeker', 'Non-Ukrainian nationals', and 'Russian citizens'.
answers.bResponse:
You can enter Romania with temporary protection, with the right of short-stay (for Ukrainian nationals with a valid passport), or as an asylum seeker. Non-Ukrainian nationals may enter for transit purposes with a visa on arrival, and specific rules apply to Russian citizens.

For detailed information, please visit the website `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania` and read under the sections like 'Temporary protection', 'Short stay', 'Asylum seeker', 'Non-Ukrainian nationals', and 'Russian citizens'. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Ukrainian nationals can enter Romania with a valid passport for a short stay. However, they can also enter without a passport by requesting asylum at the border.

To find this detailed information, please visit the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look under the section titled 'Identity documents'.
answers.bResponse:
Ukrainian nationals can enter Romania with a valid passport for a short stay. However, they can also enter without a passport by requesting asylum at the border.

To find this detailed information, please visit the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look under the section titled 'Identity documents'. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Yes, individuals can apply for asylum within Romania at a later point after entering the country.

To find this detailed information on a webpage, you would typically look under sections related to "Entering Romania" or specifically "Asylum seeker" on a page similar to `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania`.

To find this detailed information on a webpage, you would typically look under sections related to "Entering Romania" or specifically "Asylum seeker" on a page similar to `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania`. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Temporary protection in Romania is granted for a period of one year and can be automatically extended for periods of 6 months, for a maximum of one additional year, if the generating situation persists.

To find this information on the webpage, look for the section titled "Temporary protection".
answers.bResponse:
Temporary protection in Romania is granted for a period of one year and can be automatically extended for periods of 6 months, for a maximum of one additional year, if the generating situation persists.

To find this information on the webpage, look for the section titled "Temporary protection". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
All children coming from Ukraine are accepted into Romania. It is advisable to carry an identity document of the minor or a birth certificate, but written parental approval is not required to cross the border.

To find more detailed information, please visit the website 'dopomoha.ro' and look for the section titled "Entering Romania", specifically under the "Minors" heading.

answers.answer:
Unaccompanied children from Ukraine are picked up by a team at the border crossing point and taken to DGASPC locations or professional foster carers in the area, where they receive basic services, including psychological counseling if required.

To find this information on the webpage, go to https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read under the "Minors" section.

answers.answer:
Yes, Ukrainian men between the ages of 18 and 60 are allowed to enter Romania if they meet the conditions for leaving Ukraine and entering Romania. Boys under 18 and men over 60 can also leave Ukraine and enter Romania.

You can find this detailed information on the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania under the section titled "Men".
answers.bResponse:

You can find this detailed information on the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania under the section titled "Men". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
No, there is no requirement to present a certificate of vaccination or a valid PCR test to enter Romania from Ukraine. You are also not required to quarantine or fill in the Digital Form for Entering Romania.

To find this information on the webpage, go to https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look under the "Covid-19" section.

To find this information on the webpage, go to https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look under the "Covid-19" section. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Non-Ukrainian nationals (Third Country Nationals) who resided in Ukraine and hold a passport can enter Romania for transit purposes, obtaining a transit visa on arrival valid for up to 90 days. They must have a valid travel document and do not need to visit a consulate first.

For detailed information, please visit the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and refer to the section titled "Non-Ukrainian nationals".
answers.bResponse:
Non-Ukrainian nationals (Third Country Nationals) who resided in Ukraine and hold a passport can enter Romania for transit purposes, obtaining a transit visa on arrival valid for up to 90 days. They must have a valid travel document and do not need to visit a consulate first.

For detailed information, please visit the website dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and refer to the section titled "Non-Ukrainian nationals". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Yes, you can bring your pet when entering Romania from Ukraine, even if it is not vaccinated against rabies or identified with a microchip/tattoo. You will need to fill in a Pet Location Form and complete all necessary formalities after entering Romania.

You can find this detailed information on the website `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania` under the "Animals" section.
answers.bResponse:

You can find this detailed information on the website `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania` under the "Animals" section. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
Russian citizens who have a residence permit in Ukraine do not need a visa to enter Romania. If coming from the Russian Federation, they will need a visa and must apply online first for verifications on the Eviza.ro portal to get an appointment at the Consular Section.

To find this information on the webpage, navigate to the section titled "Russian citizens."
answers.bResponse:

To find this information on the webpage, navigate to the section titled "Russian citizens." For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

answers.answer:
The available border crossing points for entering Romania directly from Ukraine are Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, Rădăuți-Prut, and Isaccea. You can also enter Romania via the Republic of Moldova.

To find this detailed information on a webpage, look for a section titled "Border crossing From Ukraine".

To find this detailed information on a webpage, look for a section titled "Border crossing From Ukraine". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania

Yes, it is possible to enter Romania through the Republic of Moldova.

To find more detailed information, visit the website `https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania` and read under the section titled "Entering Romania through the Republic of Moldova".

Real-time waiting times for border crossings into Romania can be found at https://www.politiadefrontiera.ro/ro/traficonline/.

To find this information, go to the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and scroll down to the "Border crossing" section, where you will find the link to "Real-time waiting times for every border crossing into Romania".

answers.answer:
You can call the National Council for Refugees (CNRR) at +40 730 073 170 for questions about access into Romania.

To find more detailed information, please visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look under the "Border crossing" section, specifically for the part discussing "For questions about access into Romania".

No, there is no official transport organized from the Romanian border points at the moment; however, there are a few voluntary initiatives.

To find this information on the webpage, go to https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and scroll down to the section titled "Transport from the Romanian border".

NGOs at border crossings provide food and guidance. For other resources like accommodation, food, clothing, or transportation, you can use platforms like Sprijin de Urgență and Un Acoperiș.

To find detailed information, visit the website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and look for the sections titled "Sprijin de Urgență" and "Un Acoperiș" towards the bottom of the page.
